title: Connect.

And the startup founders at the beginning decided to give 10% of the equity.
For good and and that 10% became some of that work and we started about a year, year and a half ago with looking at.
Kind of implementing the mission of using data for social impact.
And it's not only about data, but also using a startup mindset of implementing that, and the theme that came to mind really was.
Looking back at the last year.

With with the solutions.

And the first thing is really, and that's, I think, many of us who work in kind of transition to the social impact spaces.
It's almost a transformational experience because we have been working in marketing before.
And I'm not doing this and and the motivations are very different.
Sometimes people look for better problems, so they look for.
To to have different you know, to work on their skills.
So it's it's really interesting like to look at your motivation like how?
How can we use this power or how do you want to use this power?
Of using data and.
The.
What's really interesting is that the volunteers and the staff that we have are really very high-quality, so I I'm not quite sure if there's a shortage of people wanting to do this.
I think there's a lot of.
Great talent and.
And I think interesting people want to solve interesting problems.
Does it work?
Oh, OK. And really, the use case seems to be for us.
These are kind of the four areas we're working on now.
Is data really helps us understand risk?
If you look at the.
Homeless person, like what happened before that person became homeless, something happened.
What are the risk factors here?
What happened before a student takes prescription drugs and becomes addicted?
What happens before a student drops out?
So it's really a version of social risk management.
And if we can anticipate things.
We can prevent and the opportunity really is prevention when we look at social data and I would like to share one.
Up one project, it's.
With the city of New York we worked with the Department of.
Homeless prevention and this is what you see in blue.
All the evictions in New York City in the last four years.
So evictions are everywhere.
What you see in white are evictions that are.
That led to a shelter entry so it really shows like the structure of of a given problem now and.
But that's not the solution.
That's the data, and we can see that we can see the problem, but it's not quite the solution at the point.
Is to make it actionable and it becomes actionable when it becomes personal.
So this is you know, pilot area where we used kind of an implementation.
The risk, so the red dots and red are families that are served an eviction and are likely to become homeless after the eviction.
And the white ones are the families that became that.
They've got an eviction but have a lower risk.
So this is actionable information and.
And the question is like how can we?
How can this be applied?
This is where the data science stops and where the implementation starts and and what we really learned is that.
We have to connect.
With the people who do the intervention, the data is only useful if you.
If that is used by someone who can make the change, and that's maybe not us, and sitting down and.
Talking about like how the intervention looks like, because intuition is to knock on doors and save families, but that didn't work.
The actual.
Version of using the data.
Let me try this.
Is 2 is to send a letter, so it's literally a communication problem where we send.
All of the dots.
The people who are at risk of becoming homeless, a letter and telling them how they can avoid to become homeless.
And that really made the difference.
And this really is the point.
When you look at data like how can we iterate so it becomes useful in that it has an impact.
And we piloted in four different areas we put in one area with three benchmark areas and we had a 50% left left in high risk.
Entrance to the prevention system.
So it works and it works very well.
So this is kind of our final kind of words that I think we have to track also.
So it's the implementation but also the tracking of the implementation.
And.
Alone in three months, this three months in this little district, I think we addressed, or we could.
I think we can save about 40 families like what if we scaled that?
And it is scalable.
And this is my final word, really.
I think the really key, I think skill is to not do it for them, but do it with them.
I think this is a different project where we work on.
Prostitution arrests in in New York City where we kind of presented the data to stakeholders and I think that really makes.
I think it's a difference when a data scientist or when the data science becomes problem solving and becomes innovation when we sit down and can really discuss and interact with the data.
And and truly explore the data with the people who who make the difference.

For me.
Check them out.
